key_insight: Spatia keeps a persistent 3D point-cloud as spatial memory and iteratively generates short video clips conditioned on — and updating — that memory via visual SLAM, yielding much better long-term spatial and temporal consistency.
problem_solved: Current video generators lose coherence over long sequences because they lack an explicit, updatable scene representation to preserve static geometry and align temporal dynamics.
method: Maintain a persistent 3D scene point-cloud as spatial memory to represent static geometry.
Generate video clips conditioned on the spatial memory with an explicit dynamic–static disentanglement.
Continuously update the spatial memory using visual SLAM from generated/viewed frames to propagate consistency across clips.
impact: Enables more coherent, long-horizon video synthesis — useful for robotics, AR/VR, simulation, and any application needing consistent scene geometry across time. Decouples static scene representation from temporal dynamics to scale generation quality.
visual_elements: Pipeline loop diagram: Spatial memory → Clip generator → Frames → Visual SLAM → Memory update
Side-by-side comparison of long-sequence outputs: baseline vs Spatia (showing improved spatial/temporal coherence)
3D point-cloud visualization overlayed with RGB frames to show persistent scene memory
Timeline/clip-stitching illustration showing iterative clip generation and memory propagation
paper_title: Spatia: Video Generation with Updatable Spatial Memory
paper_authors: Jinjing Zhao, Fangyun Wei, Zhening Liu, Hongyang Zhang, Chang Xu
